I was looking for an accessory to mount a microphone on my camera. I choose to use the standard mounting platform for camera and simply add a screw (buy anywhere).
To have a good precision for mounting it and have simple part to print, I think it's better to thermoforming it rather than build a complex shape layer by layer.
I needed it for a microphone but it can be used for others accessories...
I choose to build it flat and thermoforming it. With a hot air gun it's pretty easy to form and weld it (around 240Â°C or less). http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oALpKrW_Sw0

Climbing hold for indoor rock climbing.  Accepts a 3/8" bolt.
The openscad puts random spheres (with random offset and number of facets) around a central cube to ensure a good attachment point.  Play with the seed, add more spheres, go nuts!
Tested on a bouldering wall, SportRock in Sterling VA.  I think it'd be better to enlarge it, but of course I was worried about strength.  The size that it is, you can't really crank on it so it's stable, if a bit slippery.

Print, bolt to wall with a 3/8" carriage bolt.
I printed it with 2 extra layers and 50% hexagonal infill, in blue translucent PLA.  It's pretty solid, and gives no indication of being weak.

description.text:
Printable vent screw for stand up paddleboards*. It probably needs some o-ring grease* to get a watertight seal. I printed it at 100% infill. These don't have any cuts perpendicular to the threads, so they probably wont vent as rapidly as some of the others when partially loosened. I made these so I don't have to use surf wax next time I misplace my vent plugs. I think there are a few different thread styles so I'm not sure which boards this design will fit. This design has a 1.5mm pitch and threads are approximately 12mm in diameter. The slot is sized to be tightened using a quarter. I also added a threaded vent plug holder, made for attaching to a leash. Printer:
-- Eustathios Filaments: (full list can be found on thrinter)
-- eSun Red ABS
-- Sainsmart Transparent Red TPU
-- NinjaFlex Fire TPE *affiliate link

description.text: plug-shaped toy
This simple object does one thing - combine 4 pencils.  With four of them you can make an open-bottom cube with room to expand upwards; with 8, a two-story building.

Based strongly on a 4-way PVC joiner from the hardware store, inspired by a lifetime of exposure to tinker toys and Construx.  Designed in FreeCAD using the Sketch->Part Design workbench, starting with a hexagon, then padding and slicing from there.
To the best of my knowledge this is an original work; I certainly started from scratch, anyway.

Scale 1: Preschool to Elementary Any kid old enough not to try to eat their toys can enjoy this - just like big market toys, you stick the rods together with pretty plastic connectors. Set goals appropriate for their grade level - maybe the fifth graders can have a competition to build the tallest building or the strongest bridge, working individually/in groups/as a class. Scale 2: Junior High School and up Orthogonal building blocks are fun, but if you really want to make a structure you're going to need diagonals. Using the attached files, make a 45° pencilgrabber that can slide anywhere along the middle of the pencil. Whose design works the best? Can the clips themselves be improved? What if they bowed in the middle like a binder clip instead of flexing out like a paperclip? Objectives Any student building a structure will gain valuable experience in what does and doesn't support; students working together learn teamwork, students working separately learn independence, and students reworking the model learn 3D modeling. Audiences Any grades K-12 can use this, it is infinitely scalable; college students may be bored by the triviality of the tasks, depending on their background. Preparation Have students save their pencils throughout the year, or bring in a fresh package from the dollar store or similar; a single twelve-pack can get you two feet off the ground, if the whole class is working together you may need a higher ceiling. Steps
  • Print a series of these objects in advance
  • If editing, I recommend using the FCStd file when available - it has an Undo history stretching clear back to the first step, complete with the original geometries.
  • You may want to have diagonals and/or 6-sided variants available - Joiner5 allows construction beyond the simple tower, Joiner6 allows construction in all orthogonal directions. (I tried doing the 45°s as well on a single box, with predictably disasterous results - but the whole point is to invent your own blocks, not for me to make you evetry possible block!)
  • I've never used the Customizer, but if that lets you delete items you could probably get away with just using Joiner6 for everything and cutting off the parts you don't want.
  • I don't actually own a 3D Printer, so if you have any feedback on Actually Using This I'll gladly integrate it into future updates.

title: Pocket-Tactics: War of the Sundered Realms (Tile Preview)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A new (and much enhanced) edition of Pocket-Tactics is on the way, and as we gear up for a Kickstarter campaign (along with our usual open-scource releases, don't worry there) I thought we'd release some of the 3D printable tiles. The walls and pillars fit into the tiles once they've been arranged, which ensures that you can still shuffle them and build your map in random configurations. We'll have way, way more soon, but for now, get a head start on your tile situation! These are obviously useful for lots of other games (25mm/1" square grid tiles are handy that way). I included a zip file of dual-extrusion prints. These are really good if you want the brickwork on the tiles to pop, and I plan on doing some variations with the walls as well. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested to help fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy!

comments.text: This looks awesome, is there a scheduled release?
comments.author: hammer1988

comments.text: Will there be any compatibility issues (i.e. my current PT armies not working with the new version) coming up? Just asking so I can reload on filament ;P
comments.author: krisguy

comments.text: Oh, I don't think so. We'll make sure that all of the old models have stat cards. Even the very big ones, eventually. They're all the same size, it's just the tiles that are changing, and even there, we'll have modes that use the old tiles too.
comments.author: krisguy

comments.text: That's great. My kids like the hex tiles because they are different.
comments.author: dutchmogul

comments.text: Yeah, not to worry. Here's a few  hex tile previews. We'll be releasing the models pretty soon.
comments.author: krisguy

comments.text: Keep up the good work
comments.author: dutchmogul

comments.text: Thanks, Sam! Will do.
comments.author: Sam_Q

comments.text: No more hexes?
comments.author: BigBadBison

comments.text: We'll have hex-mode as well. But this will be the version that comes with the produced sets (at least until we can find a way to get hexes manufactured in our price range). Also, the hexes will be used for larger, world-map styles of play.

title: Make your belts for Automated Build Platform

description.text:
Now the software is ready to do the design of belts for cupcake abpv1.0 or others. 
In "angle mode", use 246 mm, in glue mode use 239 mm, just dont ask me "why..."
Well, I tryed very lengths, but what fit exactly with AB is 239 x 84 in glue mode (high temperature silicone glue). But need some hack in motor that need to polish with emery wheel of dremel where the belt shoud contact. Make the belt, put a little bit of glue over rectangles of glue, fits and wait one or two day to install (silicone glue needs time).
Other option, that is better is attach by a hot flat plate. That I use.
Unzip and use. You need a laser printer as defaut printer and it dpi of printing must be same of software, 600 dpi is good, but you can use any dpi of your printer.

description.text: Moved to https://www.youmagine.com/designs/rummikub-tile-holders I do not support companies forcing lawsuits based on trivial patents against other 3D printer companies. My tile holder works well at home, but is too large for the box of the Rummikub travel edition, and too hard to disassemble every time. This remix is easy to handle, but somewhat more fragile. Use a rasp to make the parts fit, do not press the bars too much, brute force will break the side parts. I recommend to print a few spare side parts for longer journeys. Btw: Thingiverse people, instructions are now hidden in a separate tab, who will ever read them? And please give us a filter that allows to hide all that customized stuff which floods Thingiverse.

UPDATE: 2/11/2016 - New items added, check below
I have designed this 180mm Quadcopter from scratch straight up using Tinkercad. This is a beta version so some flaws might be present, feel free to remix it just don't forget to credit me :)
Photos are just for a Demo, you can assemble this anyway you like, also with or without the Middle Frame, the arms can only hold 1806 motors and maybe smaller, but i haven't tried that yet, also there is a cutout for the ESCs in the arm. I made this 180mm because my print bed is pretty small and I love how strong and durable these mini quads are, this takes about 7-9 hours depending on how much infill you want to print with. Quantity:
1 Bottom Frame
1 Top Frame
4 Arms
1 Middle Frame (optional) Suggested Parts:
ESCs: http://www.banggood.com/DYS-BL16A-Mini-16A-BLHeli-ESC-OPTO-2-4s-for-RC-Multicopter-p-975796.html (These will fit perfectly) Motors: 1806 2300KV motors will fit (X or + Mounting)
Smaller motors might work but try at your own risk Props: ABS or Carbon 3030 Props http://www.banggood.com/Gemfan-3030-ABS-Propeller-Prop-2CW2CCW-4-PCs-For-RC-Quadcopter-p-1005548.html
http://www.banggood.com/Gemfan-3030-Carbon-Fiber-Propeller-Set-CWCCW-For-100-180-Glass-Frame-Kit-RC-Multirotors-p-987468.html Flight Controller: One that's 36mm x 36mm will fit perfectly
http://www.banggood.com/Afro-Naze32-10DOF-Rev5-MPU6050-Flight-controller-p-1007113.html PDB: this is the one i have mounted in the photos
http://www.banggood.com/CC3D-Flight-Controller-5V-12V-BEC-Output-Power-Distribution-Board-PCB-p-973352.html Battery: 2-3S I have a Zippy Compact 1500mah but a 1300mah may fit better
Something with a 60C should work good with the 16A ESCs UPDATE: 2/11/2016
ADDED 3 Mounts for the top of frame

  • A Gopro mount, I recommend using short M3 bolts and some matching locknuts to secure mount safely (nylon screws used only for demonstration)

  • A 22.5 degree tilt designed around this camera ( http://www.banggood.com/600TVL-8_0MP-14-2_8mm-CMOS-FPV-170-Degree-Wide-Anlge-Lens-Camera-PALNTSC-p-984345.html ). I used some 3M double sided tape to secure it to my frame but the lens hole is pretty precise after you clean it out after printing.

  • A no tilt mount designed around the same camera above. I used 3M tape to secure the camera to my frame with this mount also.
    • IF YOU GUYS NEED A 45 DEGREE MOUNT LET ME KNOW IN THE COMMENTS AND I'LL MODIFY THE DESIGN AND ADD IT. Any questions please ask ! Enjoy this frame !

Support needed for the bottom and top frame holes where bolts or nuts can slide into
Support needed for middle frame where it clips into the top frame
Print speed 3600 mm/min
Designed in Tinkercad

Some deck dividers I whipped up quickly for my brother. They are symbols for the magic lands. They are designed to be thin so they have a slight flexibility if printed in abs (which is what I print most things in) and so they don't take up too much room in a deck box. I am not positive they will fit all deck boxes so check yours before printing. Dividers are 2.7 x 3.9 inches.
Ignore the strange spots on the rendered image. I am having a driver issue after upgrading to win10 and just haven't decided to figure out and fix the issue yet. They print thick enough that there are no odd spots of light shining through them.

description.text: Note: I have been told that some of my models do not come out the right size on certain programs. The proper length for these is 2 inches. If it is not 2 inches in your software, please scale the whole object to meet that length. This is a simple set of bracers for the flimsy fold out cup holders in older model audis. These are only useful for cup holders which have cracked plastic where the back of the cup holder armature connects into the socket, causing the whole cup holder to bend downward when a heavy drink is placed in it. This video does a better job explaining how to remove and disassemble the cup holder than I can with words: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qPfmNJk1UXk He is solving a different problem, but the disassemble and reassembly are useful. Credit goes to its creator, I am not responsible for the video. Once the cupholder assembly is removed from the sleeve, you will see where the cracks in the armature are (I will include photos above). These bracers are intended to be glued down over the cracked area and distribute the load to the rear of the assembly (use gorilla glue and clamps to make sure the bond is strong and the pieces are flush). If you get glue in the small cutout area where there is a pivot hole, make sure you clear the glue from that joint or you risk inhibiting the unfolding action of the cupholder (can be cleared with a knife after the glue is dry, gorilla glue can just be picked off). Once clamped for at least 12 hours, and left to rest another 12 hours, reassemble the unit and put it back in your car. If you print in black you can't even tell they are there. The bracers as a pair are rated for 4lbs which is 64oz of water. After installing them on my dash cup holder, I have successfully held a 32oz drink without any flex. The two rear cup holders, and the in dash cup holder all have the same design and can use this bracer. I don't know what models or years were the same, but I have a 2001 A6 which is what I based the models on.

Notes: Due to the thickness of the part and the stress applied to it, I recommend printing as small a layer height as you can manage and as high an infill as you can. I printed the top and bottom layers so thick that there was no infill. I also recommend only printing from ABS. Stress analysis was done with properties for ABS, and I am not sure PLA will hold up without flexing or even breaking. I print almost exclusively in ABS so I don't have experience with PLA but I know it has lower strength but higher elasticity. Pulling this off the bed, it will feel flimsy. It is very delicate when bent across the thin area perpendicularly to the part. It purposely has strength in the parallel direction because all the force will be placed on it in that direction and once glued down it should experience zero force perpendicular to the surface.

My implementation of the "Evolution Door" (Drehplattentür, which translates as the "flip panel door") designed by Klemens Torggler. I first encountered this as the "folding gate" animated GIF. I loved it, so I figured out how it worked, and designed my own 3D printable version. Subsequently, I found that it was designed by Austrian kinetic artist Klemens Torggler, and can be found at http://www.dezeen.com/2014/02/11/door-reinvented-with-folding-mechanism-by-klemens-torggler/ My design can be found at https://cad.onshape.com/documents/56aa9d70e4b05aaf9b8ae389/w/179c3d1482a1f59f6f3a3ffa or search Public documents at OnShape.com for "Evolution Door". Movie is at https://www.dropbox.com/s/55ulfiac9z6l4uy/20160130_133552.mp4?dl=0

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15% is fine

Notes: In Slic3r, make sure the "Only infill where needed" box is not checked... that makes for weak parts. Increase the number of perimeters and top and bottom shells to make it stronger. Smaller layer height would probably also make for a smoother ball and socket. I've included both the print-in-place "Ball Joint" file and the separate "ball" and "socket" files. If you print the "Ball Joint", you don't need the separate ones. If you print separately, you'll somehow need to get them together. If your print is sufficiently sloppy, there shouldn't be a problem. Or you could try pausing the "socket" print when it's nearly finished and put the ball in place before completing. NB: The ball triangle is assymetric and must be put in the right way up. You'll need to print 2 of the "Triangle1" parts... both can be printed at once, even on a 100x100 printer

If you've printed with PLA and you find the socket is too loose and the ball falls out, you could try pouring a little boiling water on the socket and bend it into place. You could probably also use this trick to get the two parts together if you've printed them separately.
You'll probably also need to drill through the holes. The outer corner holes in the Triangle1 pieces are 3mm, and the hinge axle holes are 2mm. I designed it to use 1.75mm filament as the axles, but wire or whatever of the right diameter will do.
You will also need a door frame to mount it on... 2 x 3mm holes, 132mm apart, and a couple of M3 bolts as the hinges.

A design goal for me was to keep the outside of the door as flat as possible, so that (a) the mechanism would be hidden (and make it more magical), and (b) it would be more door-like. But then I decided to save filament by having cut-outs in the panels. :roll-eyes: The biggest difficulty I had was with the ball joint. As a personal challenge, I had decided to make that a print-in-place mechanism. My printer is getting a bit loose and inaccurate, so I continually either wound up with everything welded into one piece, or the parts would be so weak they would break. In this current design the back of the socket is still quite weak. The hole in the top of the socket is a key thing for print-in-place to work, so that the ball can start printing from the bed. Because my printer is a bit sloppy, I have deliberately left a gap of 1.75mm between parts. If you have a well-behaved printer, you could reduce this for a much nicer product. Each side is 66mm long, just so it will fit on my 100mmx100mm printer. Anyone wanting to scale it up will need to go back to my source design. You can't scale it up in your slicer unless you scale uniformly in all 3 dimensions (otherwise you won't get a round ball and socket) in which case it would become very thick. For ease of printing, the parts are the same thickness as the ball diameter (12mm). Thinner would be nicer, but the smaller the ball, the harder it is to print, and the weaker the axle attaching the ball to its triangle. Another aesthetic improvement would be to hide the ball and socket completely inside the triangles, like Torggler's door. In mine, I was careful to keep all the hinges and ball on the same plane and inline because I figured that would keep the geometry simple. I don't know what the effect of putting the ball and socket inside the triangle instead of at the corner of the triangle might be. So there's lots more for people to experiment with here, if they feel so inclined. You can find my design at https://cad.onshape.com/documents/56aa9d70e4b05aaf9b8ae389/w/179c3d1482a1f59f6f3a3ffa/e/dbbc208f93b85709c29d29c2

comments.text: You need a couple of M3 screws to act as axles. You can drill the axle holes in any piece of wood or metal or whatever. When I designed this, I decided (since I only had a small printer with a 100x100 bed) that it was better to make something whose parts were the size of the printer than make the whole thing fit in that space -- a tiny doorway 100x50mm. Go ahead and contribute to the community by publishing a door frame as a remix.
comments.author: TheFisherOne

comments.text: The ball joint and socket can be printed assembled, or printed separately and assembled later....I've included both the print-in-place "Ball Joint" file and the separate "ball" and "socket" files. If you print the "Ball Joint", you don't need the separate ones. If you print separately, you'll somehow need to get them together. If your print is sufficiently sloppy, there shouldn't be a problem. Or you could try pausing the "socket" print when it's nearly finished and put the ball in place before completing. NB: The ball triangle is assymetric and must be put in the right way up.

These risers will provide about 5" of clearance between the bottom of the TOM with the electronics and the parts that do the printing. This is enough (for me, at least) to work fairly easily on just about any of the individual pc boards to check voltages, swap cables, etc. These risers are designed to work in conjunction with the excellent large and small TOM feet designed by Deltatgear: http://www.thingiverse.com/deltagear and Fillibar: http://www.thingiverse.com/fillibar. Thanks to the two of them for those original designs. This combination makes a nice stable support for the printing mechanism, enough so that I probably won't remove them even when I stop fooling around with the electronics, if that day ever comes.

To get the ~5" of clearance you will need to have already printed 4 each of the smaller and larger feet: Smaller feet: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11812
Larger feet: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11414 All you need to do is fit the risers in between the bigger feet on the bottom, and the smaller feet on the top. If you have the rubber feet on the bottom piece and are bothered by the possibility of bowing, you can provide more support at the corners. One way to do that would be by printing a set of these: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13356 These could also be used with only the smaller feet on the top if not as much clearance was needed.

description.text: 3D Printers are amazing at replacing obscure parts on otherwise good items.  Is your projector missing a foot?  Remote missing a battery door?  Has the disc holding the mouseball in place cracked?  Print a new one!

Example - My mouse (pictured) lost its battery drawer a year ago, and has been held together with tape for this whole time - but a few minutes sketching out the dimensions and a new one is ready to print!

description.header: Project - replace every broken item in the school
description.text:
Objectives Students participating in this project will learn the value of items, how to measure and replicate missing items, how to keep an inventory, how to take good notes, teamwork, and how to properly constrain a sketch. Additionally, everyone participating gets the sense of accomplishment at having saved an object from being scrapped out. Audiences Younger and ameture students can help by finding and listing everything broken in the school, along with where these items can be found; intermediate students can measure and suggest how to design replacement parts; expert students can design and print the replacement parts. Preparation Accurate measuring tools and a basic understanding of how to use them are vital to intermediate and expert levels; novices will only need writing materials. Steps! This is a small project, best suited to Extra Credit - although if the first student finds enough things to fix, it could well take an entire class of students to design all the replacements!
  • Find everything broken. This would be an excellent example for Delegation - one teacher asks all the other teachers to make a list of what they'd like fixed - or you can send the students out searching.
  • One student or a small team of appraisers go out to catalog everything broken - this can be based on the list from Step 1, or they can hunt them down on their own.
  • More experienced students go through the list and take measurements, sketching out what needs to be replaced (this can be combined with the previous steps based on skill levels)
  • The most experienced students design the replacement parts and print them
  • subject to the school's union agreement, the school's maintenance person can then install the replacement part
    • Results A perfect score would be everything replaced in a timely manner with no misprints; how many points that is worth is subject to the teacher's discretion, naturally.

title: Robot Action Figure - One Piece Print - 19 Points of Articulation

description.text:
Action figures are great, robots are great, and action figure robots are double great. You know what's not great? Assembling things. Adding rubber bands/pins/glue, all of that is not so great. There has to be a better way! Well now there is: He can stand, he can kneel, he can make all the great poses you've always wanted to do! I only wish all the action figures I grew up with had this level of pose-ability. It's ORANGE BOT! IF PEOPLE LIKE ORANGE BOT HE WILL BE FOLLOWED WITH ACCESSORIES / VEHICLE / VILLAIN FIGURES I was wandering through Thingiverse when I came across this:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:618752 I thought it looked really cool, but wandering through the comments I found people were having trouble printing it. So I took a gander at the file and for my set-up, it was full of gaps in the model, stray planes/lines and what not and it had several joint types. I tried to print it, didn't fit together, so I tried printing it 3x as big to see if my printer isn't accurate enough for something as small as the original model, still didn't fit together. I'm a bit of a clean-model snob so I was going to fix it, but then I decided to just build a new one from scratch. The whole figure prints (with supports) in one piece and has 19 points of articulation, each with a ball and socket joint. It pops off the print bed ready to pose and play. All you have to do is give each of the joints a spin to break any internal supports and it's good to go. Please expand the photos to see them full size (it seems to be cutting off parts in the preview). As usual i'm printing on LOW quality and with as little infill as possible because i'm cheap! But if you have a decent infill and print on med/high quality he should look pretty great! I'll upload a video of the print, removal from the print bed, and immediate posing of the figure. Here's the thing (skip to 50 seconds in):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lWBjVHjzMQA&feature=youtu.be Update 1 - Decided to turn this generic robot into Optimus Prime (because why not) so that will be along shortly. Preview image up there of work in progress.

comments.text: This looks great and I'd like to try printing one. What orientation did you use when printing. It looks to me that it should be vertical but I'd to be sure.
comments.author: stevemaker

comments.text: The weakest direction is aways along the Z axis of your printer because that is where the layers will come apart under stress. However, prints are very strong in the X and Y direction. For the strongest part print it horizontally as shown in the STL preview. You will need a little bit of support inside the handle, but it comes out very strong that way.
comments.author: stevemaker

comments.text:
Yes, the geometry was totally wrong in that file. I must have somehow posted one of the intermediate files from before I had it all cleaned up. Anyway, it is fixed now and has been posted. You were a tremendous help in pointing out the problem. I wish more people would speak up when they see something wrong with one of my projects. I test everything a lot, but Murphy's law seems to be one step ahead of me at times. Thanks again.
Richard

title: Power Switch Box for Geeetech Full Metal Aluminium Printer

description.text:
The printer came with just the wiring and switches and after 2 shocks from touching the power lead when switching on, I decided to make a box to cover these wires. Also makes the unit look cooler. This is a modified version of this model:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:806826 Resized it, added the power plug and voila. Protection. I intend screwing this onto the back of the PSU.

Printer:

Geeetech Full Metal Aluminium Prusa X3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes: I actually printed this without any supports. If at all supports may be needed for the hole of the Power plug. Any droop can be filed away and is hidden by the plug itself. I did not need supports for the top of the box because of the slope. Sketchup STL included in case any mods needed. You could add a logo or your name like I did.
Screw it onto the holes on the PSU. You may need 2 more holes drilled. NO MORE SHOCKS!
Modified in Sketchup 2016

comments.text: also, when its high tolerance parts like this, increase the size by 1%-2% to compensate the shrinkage of the material. Even more if youre using ABS filament

comments.text: id recommend supports. What slicer do you use? If youre printing this in cura, try craftware for prints like this since with craftware you can pick and choose your supports and where they are along with how much support. It's the closest free slicer to simplfy3D

description.text:
I made a few modifications on the design, making it a tighter fit on both the printer and the cooling fan. No more need of tape, it sticks very firmly together.
This also means that it's more difficult to install: you'll want to use a softer material like PETG or ABS, that bends a little when putting in place.
I also improved the airflow, there is more air coming through the vent now.
It's intended to be used with a 24V 50x50x15 mm blower fan. Check out the original thing for details on how to wire the fan to the circuit. The fan adds a half inch width on the back, which might collide with the bed support when starting from home position (with bed all the way up) and moving all the way to the left. I recommend printing a shim for the Y axis.
  • Updated on 1/31/2016 to direct the airstream a little lower, directing the airflow away from the extruder.

description.text: Just a simple Undertale Heart I made.

• Be bored
  • Have family unexpectedly call you to say hi.
  • Grab mouse
  • Googled Undertale Heart
  • Trace Undertale Heart
  • Make heart.
  • Finish making heart
  • Hang up phone
  • Question yourself and reality on why you did this to yourself and reevaluate your life.

title: BreadBoard Buddy
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple tool to allow power to be supplied to the side rails of a bread board from an outside power supply.
I had originally designed it with female banana plugs, but it was a little bulky for the pins alone to hold it on.  A simple remix would be to get rid of the single hole, and add a pair of holes for two bolts to come through for screw posts.

Get some perfboard that the holes will line up with the outside rails on each side.  Cut the board down to fit within the box (see dimension pic), mine was 3x20 holes.  Drill 2 4mm holes in the perfboard so they line up with the mounting holes.  Tap the mounting holes with an M3 tap.  Vapor smooth/harden the print as desired here.  
While the print is hardening, solder 2 2x3 (or 4 1x3) header pins on each end of the perfboard.  Mine had to bend a slight bit to fit into the breadboard.  Run a wire to the corresponding pins on the each side (If you want both rails to be powered).  Run the power wires through the hole in the top of the box, solder your power line to the appropriate pins.    Pull the power wire through the hole till the perfboard pulls up against the box and place a small zip tie on the power cord just below where the board pulled tight, this will help prevent stressing the solder joints.  
You can wire this as you wish.  If you want both rows on one side ground, wire it as such.  Mine is as marked on the breadboard (4 channels).   Just remember to note which side is positive and which is negative.  Mine is marked to indicate the outside channel polarity.  
Mount the board using M3 screws.

description.text: A flexible LED tool light for the Taig lathe and mill. This light is designed to fit in the right slot of the Taig headstock. Based on a 10mm super bright LED. Design files include the stl files, a parts list that includes all materials and tools required to construct the light and a schematic to help with electronics construction. These were printed in black and orange ABS.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: Used a 20 line brim instead of a raft

Construction Tips The holes in the base need to be tapped for 2-56 threads. The power switch is glued into the recess of the base. The base cover is secured to the base using 2-56 screws. In my example these were socket head machine screws, but any 2-56 thread machine screw should work. The leads on the 10mm LED need to be significantly trimmed back prior to soldering in order for the LED to fit in the housing. Taig Tool Light Schematic Taig Tool Light Control Box

remixed_from.title: Camera Lens Cap Holder - 67mm for R-Strap

description.text:
When I saw Technophobe's 67mm lens cap holder, I knew I had to have one for my own lenses, so I went about making a 72mm lens variation (which worked for both my primary lenses sigma / nikon).   
I added a cutout for the lens cap locking feature, as well as a text label to help me keep track. The strap arms fit a 36mm strap.  
I'm working on a customizable holder so you can change the size to fit your own lenses.   
Credit to Technophobe for the idea!

I printed this at 100% infill on my Rep 2X with no support.
Build plate temperature 120degC.

It is a bit tight getting the handle in, i'll admit I had to file the holes a bit, since it was only a one off I have not adjusted the design.

Lesson Plans and lab work is now available on my teacher pay teacher site, https://www.teacherspayteachers.com/Product/3D-Printable-DNA-RNA-Manipulative-Lab-1-3452084 This is a set of restriction enzymes to expand upon my DNA/RNA Manipulative set. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1259352 These 4 restriction enzyme blocks can be used to model how they work, and how gene splicing / recumbent DNA works. The blocks also show how many restriction enzymes are palindromes with sticky ends. Your students will enjoy simulating genetic engineering with this expansion set. This features EcoRI, BamHI, Hindll, and Kpnl Restriction enzymes. There are over 600 of these restriction enzymes used in gene splicing. If you want to make your own restriction enzymes for gene editing, I punished an expansion set here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1321230 A partial list of restriction enzymes can be found here, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_restriction_enzyme_cutting_sites If you want other restriction enzymes made, I can make them on commission. PM me or contact me via [email protected] for details.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.3-.4 mm

Infill:

5%

Notes: I printed them in clear filament so they can lay over a DNA sequence and you can find where they match. Break all sharp edges. If you can't see the lettering, use a permanent marker to highlight the edge of the letters. Print 2 of each enzyme so you can model the cutting pattern and cleaved fragments.
Clean up After printing break any sharp edges. I found a emery board works great for rough edges. If you print clear, use a permanent marker to highlight the edge of the lettering.

Design and printing These were designed in TinkerCAD based on the previous DNA / RNA file. They were designed to fit as one piece so you can see how they work, and save time building them with the other set. If you want to expand and make your own, DL my expansion set here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1321230

Project: Gene Splicing and Restriction Enzymes This Is to expand upon the DNA / RNA manipulative set. Your students will see how gene splicing, and how restriction enzymes are used to splice new genes into an organism. You can visit https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_restriction_enzyme_cutting_sites for a list of restriction enzymes and their cutting sites. You can make your own with this expansion set http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1321230 Objectives Students will understand what genetic modification is.
Students will model how restriction enzymes work.
Students will model gene splicing.
Students will demonstrate how to alter DNA.
Students will discuss the ethics and implications of genetic modification.
Students will discuss genetically modified organisms (GMO's) and agriculture.
Students will show their knowledge of DNA and RNA.
Students will model how mecumbant DNA works.
Students will show sticky ends, fragments, and cleavage of DNA. Audiences This is for AP Biology, College Bio, Medical students, and home school students.
This can also be used by genetic councilors, doctors, and medical students. Preparation Students should learn about DNA and RNA.
Students should understand vectors and the concepts of gene splicing.
Students should know about mutations.
Students should know what paladrones are, and how they appear in DNA.
Students should know what an enzyme does.
Students should know the base pairs, what direction (5- 3) DNA is read. To use these restriction enzymes, you should print up 2 of them along with the DNA / RNA set. A activity package will soon be available, and sold on my Teacher Pay Teacher page. Printed sets of restriction enzymes will be for sale on my etsy page. Steps! a. Build a model of DNA matching the restriction enzyme.
b. Model how the restriction enzyme cuts the DNA along specific base pairs.
c. Show where the sticky ends are.
d. Use the enzymes to insert a new DNA sequence.
e. Discuss gene splicing. Show organisms that have undergone this procedure.
f. Discuss the ethics on gene splicing. Results To demonstrate knowledge of this, have the students work in small groups to demonstrate the process or teach it to others.
You can have the students make a stop-motion video of the process of gene splicing.
You can also have them show what they have learned by modeling DNA replication, RNA transcription, protein synthesis, and gene splicing to produce new proteins.
You can tie it to pop science by having them watch sections of the film Jurassic Park / Jurassic World that discuss what they did to create the dinosaurs. With that have the students model what the scientist in the film did.
